name: Abeke Rooftop
address: Soho Rooftop, 6a Ogbunike St, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos 105102, Lagos
note: Abeke is a Yoruba-themed rooftop spot with popular local meals served in an upscale setting. They are pretty popular, so you might struggle to get a seat on really busy days. They also have paint and sips.
proTip: The amala is nice but for the price, you might want a bit more protein in it. Abeke’s drinks though—that is where shit is at. Try their ishekushe martini or adigun and pair it with their seafood okro or asun penne pasta.

name: Ajoje
address: Private location
note: Ajoje, meaning 'to share,' specializes in private group dining with innovative and delicious Afro-fusion meals. Portions are huge and the ambience is warm and homely with wooden decor.
proTip: It is expensive, but ideally, book this out with your group. Singles tickets exist but are hard to get.

name: Akerele Suya
address: Akerele St, Surulere, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: One of the best suya spots in the city. Iconic sign and large crowds. Customer service gets strictly business-like on busy days.
proTip: There’s a shop next to the suya stand selling drinks, so you can pull out a few chairs and relax, but watch out for the temptation to order more suya!

name: Amala Yahoo
address: Bosun Anifowoshe St, Olakunle Ajibade St, off Olakunle Rd, Ojota, Lagos
note: A spot so iconic it basically has its own bus stop. Expect a shanty setting and iffy customer service, but the amala is top-notch.
proTip: Take-out is easier than eating there. Don’t leave without trying their ogufe.

name: Atije Experience
address: Private location
note: A five-course private dining experience with Afro-fusion meals, paired with wines or juices. Space is smaller than Ajoje but portions are just as tasty.
proTip: It’s fun alone or with a group. Everyone loosens up after a glass or two of wine.

name: Basilico
address: 15 Musa Yar' Adua St, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: An old-school Italian restaurant known for excellent pasta at lower-than-average prices. Part of the same compound as Pizzeriah, so pizzas are also available.
proTip: You can’t get it wrong with their arrabbiata, carbonara, or alla marinara.

name: B2B Lagos
address: 7b Karimu Kotun St, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: A 24/7 diner, a big win for late-night crawlers. Fast wait times and decent food, though the jollof is famously subpar.
proTip: The croissant sandwich plus strawberry, banana & mango smoothie is a favorite combo.

name: Beezus Kitchen’s K-BBQ Night
address: Private location
note: A monthly Korean barbecue private dining event. Seven courses of meat, from ribeye to pork ribs. You cook your own meat under Chef B’s guidance.
proTip: If you’re new to K-BBQ, find a veteran. The cooking can be tricky if Chef B is busy!

name: Buttermilk
address: Plot 124 T. F. Kuboye Rd, Oniru, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Known for breakfast and brunch. Has some of the best pancakes in Lagos. Underwent a renovation to a more minimalist theme.
proTip: Their cinnamon swirl pancakes are a 10/10. Pair with the triple chocolate waffle milkshake for a filling meal.

name: Canvas Concept Space
address: 36 Rasheed Alaba Williams Street, Lekki Phase 1, Lekki 105102, Lagos
note: A contemporary dining space celebrating West African cuisine. Has different menus for cocktails, lunch, and brunch. Reservations usually required for full dining.
proTip: Call or DM before going. Their guinea fowl focaccia sandwich is divine.

name: Chinatown Restaurant
address: Mega Plaza, 14B Idowu Martins St, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: An old-school Chinese spot with big crowds and large portions. No strong social media presence, but they’ve been around forever.
proTip: Chicken in sweet and sour sauce with their special fried rice is delicious. The chicken in oyster sauce and dumplings are underrated.

name: Dani Lagos
address: House 1 Plot 1501 Itirin Court I, Off Bishop Aboyade Cole St, Eti-Osa, Victoria Island, Lagos
note: A high-end spot located in The Delborough, curated by a three-star Michelin chef. Features a premium Jazz night on Fridays. Strictly corporate dress code.
proTip: Their risotto is among the best in Lagos, as are the short ribs and black cod fish. Piano (downstairs) offers an all-day cafe option.

name: Deba’s Creamery
address: 7b Wole Ariyo St, off Admiralty Way, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos
note: An ice cream favorite that also offers popsicles, banana bread, waffles, milkshakes, and more. Known for variety and event coverage.
proTip: Combine their warm banana bread with scoops of ice cream. If unsure, ask Yinka for recommendations.

name: Dough Pizza Bar
address: 17B Musa Yar' Adua St, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: A New York–style pizza spot run by the kids behind Double Four. Their hot salami pizza is legendary but the location has limited parking and a small space.
proTip: If you prefer halal, try their nduja. Pair any pizza with their frose, and if Ali is there, he’ll finish it at your table for cool videos.

name: Dulce Cafe and Bakery
address: Behind Slashpoint supermarket, 15 Glover Rd, Ikoyi, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Owned by Kajal, who started with just pastries and has now expanded to a full restaurant. Great pastries, coffee, and open-feel ambience. Pasta can be weaker, but the core pastry items are excellent.
proTip: Don’t leave without getting the cinnamon rolls or chicken pesto sandwich. They also have an unlimited cocktail deal Wed–Fri (5pm–8pm).

name: Elysium Beach Club
address: Elysium jetty End of, Foreshore Rd, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
openingHours: 1pm to 1am (closed Mon & Tue, strictly by reservation)
note: A members-only beach club with rotating menu curated by Chef Kemi. The food is surprisingly top-notch, but you need membership or a reservation.
proTip: Arrive near sunset for the best view. If it’s still on the menu, try their Elysium Spice.

name: Firewood Jollof
address: 10 Admiralty Way, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos 105102, Lagos
note: A top-tier spot for properly smoky jollof. Ambience is basic, service can be lacking, but the jollof is among the best in Lagos.
proTip: Come in person or do takeout to avoid issues with delivery orders going wrong or slow.

name: Galaxy Pizza
address: 31B Oju Olobun Cl, Local, Victoria Island, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: Offers unique pizza options (tandoori spicy chicken, shrimp scampi, etc.) plus decent milkshakes. Slightly expensive but worth it, with a large dining area.
proTip: Try their broadway fajita pizza or philly cheese steak sub. Both are must-haves.

name: Grey Matter Social Space
address: 21C Akin Ogunlewe Rd, off Ligali Ayorinde Street, Victoria Island, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: A large communal space with private cigar lounge and rooftop. Drinks are gin-heavy, food portions big and shareable. Frequent events.
proTip: Sweet potato & goat croquettes as starters, smoked turkey or fried chicken as mains, Imoteda’s bowl for dessert. Holiday at the hive sangria will knock you out!

name: Griddle and Roast
address: 9b Prince Adelowo Adedeji St, off Admiralty Way, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos 100001, Lagos
note: A small spot focusing on BBQ. Generally not too crowded, so seating is usually available. Tasty grilled options and combos.
proTip: Go for their farmhouse platter for the mini burgers. Their grilled catfish is also massive and well seasoned.

name: Hanes and Jones
address: Block 2, plot 1 Okunade bluewaters scheme, Lekki 106104, Lagos
note: An Afro-fusion spot with creative cocktails (plantain whiskey sour) and dishes (sticky zobo wings, smoked guinea fowl). Smaller space, but more affordable than some peers.
proTip: Don’t leave without trying the smoked guinea fowl and chicken pasta. Their Norwegian salmon & mash is also lit.

name: HSE Gourmet
address: 25 Babatope Bejide Cres, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Chef Nkesi’s gourmet comfort food. Cocktails are more affordable, and the food is consistent and lovingly made. Mondays are takeout only till 4pm, and Thursdays feature pasta + sangria night.
proTip: Salmon and lasagna are top hits. Pasta and sangria night also offers superb value.

name: Ile Eros
address: 14 Kafayat Abdulrasaq Street, Lekki Phase I, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Chef Eros’s Afro-fusion restaurant offering zobo habanero ribs, tozo ragu, and more. Some misses, but generally a journey across West African cuisine.
proTip: Their plantain lasagna is unbelievably good. The community, however, wants more meat in the abula.

name: Ile Iyan
address: Plot 6 Muiz Banire St, Lekki Phase 1, Lekki 100001, Lagos
note: A Yoruba-themed spot known for pounded yam. Decor, waiters in cultural attire, and dancers on Faaji Sundays. Indoors is small, and wait times can be long.
proTip: If razzmatazz isn’t your thing, try a weekday. Great black soup, and the Olowo Eko Combo with egusi/efo riro is pricey but loaded with protein.

name: Ite
address: 8 The Providence St, Lekki Phase I, Lekki 106104, Lagos
note: Lovely place for local food if you can handle the long wait. Generous portions with contemporary local decor. Artwork around.
proTip: Their seafood okro is arguably the best in Lagos. Catfish peppersoup and nkwobi are also worth trying.

name: Jamski
address: 8A Ologun Agbaje St, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Possibly the only dine-in Jamaican spot in Lagos, offering family-style Jamaican meals at fair prices. Great customer service, cozy Jamaican decor.
proTip: No, you can’t smoke here. But try their patties and brown stew oxtail—they’re so good.

name: Kaly
address: No.1 Building, 7th Floor, 1 Akin Adesola Street off Ahmadu Bello way Number One, Victoria Island, Lagos
note: An upscale restaurant with fantastic interior design, rooftop views, and well-executed dishes. Pricey, but offers a strong combination of service, ambiance, and food.
proTip: They excel with steaks, especially the ribeye. There’s a business lunch till 4pm on weekdays (two courses for 59k).

name: Little Italy
address: Ile Oja, Sanusi Fafunwa Street, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: A small spot serving some of the best Italian dishes. Tucked away near Ile Oja, and also sells cooking ingredients. It can be cramped when busy.
proTip: Their brioche with Nutella is great, and the lasagna is chef’s kiss. Pizza is hit or miss, but you’ll find discounts on certain days.

name: Mama Toyin Foods
address: 47 Arolowun street, Onipanu, Ikeja 102215, Lagos
note: A hugely popular amala spot that many content creators feature. Run by Mama Toyin for decades. Expect big crowds.
proTip: Their catfish is typically huge, though under-ordered compared to other proteins.

name: Memories of Ethiopia
address: Green House, 15 Oba Adeyinka Oyekan Ave, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: Authentic Ethiopian meals served twice a week inside the cozy Green House. Large screen for football matches. Sahara runs this with a personal touch.
proTip: Their large mixed platter offers best value. Vegetarians can opt for the vegetarian platter. The traditional coffee (bunna) is superb.

name: Milk and Honey / Gather House
address: 47 Admiralty Road, Lekki Phase 1, and 38 Norman Williams St, Ikoyi, Lagos 101233, Lagos
note: Chef Livvy’s shop for top-tier pastries, milkshakes, and more. Original location is small; Gather House offers a bigger setting with the same goodness.
proTip: Try the caramel or biscoff milkshakes. Gather House also sells female-owned products and hosts a monthly supper club.

name: Noir Lagos
address: 4A Akin Olugbade St, Victoria Island, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: A refined French-themed spot with elegant decor and top-tier service. The bread basket could be better, but the rest is great. Private dining room available.
proTip: They can cook your steak tableside black rock style. Try the filet mignon or ribeye.

name: Nok Lagos
address: 12A Akin Olugbade Street, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: An African-themed spot with an airy garden and famously pricey abula that delivers on taste. Perfect for introducing visitors to local cuisine.
proTip: Abula is popular, but the egusi soup with pounded yam and seafood okro are also bangers. They have a dedicated brunch menu too.

name: Ofada Boy
address: 1 Mba St, Surulere, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: A safe mainland choice known for top-notch ofada dishes served in leaves. Afro-centric vibe with interesting decor.
proTip: They do palm wine well, and their seafood okro is a good pick. Watch out for the occasionally hard plantain, though!

name: Ofe Uto
address: 3rd floor, Westbrook mall, 4th roundabout, beside enyo filling station, Lekki Penninsula II, Lekki 106104, Lagos
note: An Eastern-focused spot specializing in soups like ofe nsala, onugbu, fisherman soup. Crowded on weekends, so expect slower service.
proTip: Fisherman soup is a must-try. Sundays are lively with dancers and a traditional vibe.

name: Rhodes BBQ Smokehouse
address: 29 Oyeleke Street, Oregun, Ikeja 101233, Lagos
note: An American-style BBQ spot on the mainland run by Koye Rhodes. Known for ribs, burgers, and grilled chicken at fairly affordable prices.
proTip: Try the St Louis–style ribs—they fall off the bone. The double beef burger is great but often unavailable.

name: RSVP
address: 9 Eletu Ogabi St, Victoria Island, Lagos 101001, Lagos
note: An American-style restaurant and bar with a patio and pool that’s been around for a decade. Dim lights at night can make content creation tricky.
proTip: Their salmon fillet and chicken roast are top tier. Desserts like miso crème brûlée or blueberry cheesecake are also strong.

name: Sabii Chow and Grillz
address: Beside Commint Buka, Municipal B/Stop, 26 Itire Street, Idi-Araba, Lagos 101241, Lagos
note: Primarily delivery-focused, known for consistency and affordability. Their parfait is top-heavy, so consider mixing it.
proTip: Anything with their asun is good, especially the basmati rice or spaghetti. The chicken-asun shawarma is tasty but falls apart.

name: Salma’s Authentic Lebanese Cuisine
address: 20/24 Ozumba Mbadiwe Ave, Victoria Island, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: An OG spot for Lebanese/Mediterranean cuisine, known for a gorgeous terrace view and knowledgeable waiters. Usually busy at night.
proTip: The terrace is the prettiest place to eat, but you must reserve. Their shisha is good, but not as legendary as hyped.

name: Salt and Social
address: 2a Admiralty Wy, Lekki Phase 1, Lagos 105102, Lagos
note: A pub/communal space open till late, known for drinks, burgers, and desserts. Bartenders put on a good show, and the vibe is artsy.
proTip: Try the Gold Mine drink if you don’t mind sticky hands. Their burgers are top-notch, and the French toast is excellent.

name: Shark House 101
address: Aaron mall St, 12 Olubunmi Owa St, Lekki Phase 1, Lekki
note: Great variety of seafood boils and platters in an underwater-like ambiance. Service can be slow, but the quantity and variety stand out.
proTip: Skip the drinks. The loaded seafood platter can feed about six people, so it’s a mini steal.

name: Shiro
address: Block XVI 3 & 4 Victoria Island Oniru Estate, Eti-Osa, Lagos
note: An OG with gorgeous ambience, large dining space, and a full teppanyaki experience. Extensive wine collection.
proTip: Sunday brunch offers unlimited food + alcohol for 52,500. Their shisha is among the best in Lagos.

name: Sip and Cook at 22b
address: 22b Olawale Cole Onitiri Ave, Eti-Osa, Lekki 106104, Lagos
note: A cooking version of sip-and-paint. You make your own dishes (pasta, Nigerian food, etc.) with plenty of drinks in a fun group environment.
proTip: Better to come as a group. You can also purchase their locally made hibiscus mix which serves over 20 people.

name: Six Fifteen Bar and Events
address: 3, nkoroh joe street, via, Oki Ln, Mende, Lagos 100211
note: A hidden gem in Maryland. Road access is bad, service can be slow, but it’s a top peppersoup spot with huge portions.
proTip: Their large chicken pepper soup plus rice can feed four. Call ahead to place orders or risk a long wait.

name: Sushiholic Lagos
address: Block 26, Delakes Mall, 8 Admiralty Wy, Lekki 105102, Lagos
note: A small, serene Asian spot specializing in fresh sushi and fantastic BBQ short ribs. Also do great desserts and burgers.
proTip: Any sushi is outstanding, but the short rib sandwich and Jack Daniels burger are gems. End with the crème brûlée.

name: The Ona Lagos
address: 1701 Violet Yough Close, Victoria Island, 106104, Lagos
note: Chef Obehi’s highly experimental Afrocentric restaurant. Portions can be small, but the dishes are fun and creative. Rooftop bar included.
proTip: Don’t leave without trying the bao buns—they’re a standout. Smoked antelope and prosciutto or gbegiri ravioli are also winners.

name: The Rustic Deck Bar and Bistro
address: Lekki Waterside Hotel, Plot 2B Wole Olateju Cres, Lekki Phase 1, Lekki 23401, Lagos
note: Overlooks the Lekki-Ikoyi link bridge with a cozy, rustic vibe. Limited but well-executed Afro-fusion menu. Drinks can be hit or miss.
proTip: Get the chicken lollipops. The kilishi pasta with slow-cooked rabbit is among the best dishes in Lagos.

name: The Wine Lab
address: 11a, Goriola Street, Off Adeola Odeku, Victoria Island 106104, Lagos
note: A chic spot with an extensive wine collection. Known for its wine-tasting experience with a sommelier explaining everything. Cute garden-like outdoor area.
proTip: Ask for Joshua the sommelier. The seafood platter pairs well with a tasting, or go for the cheese platter.

name: Wakame Asian Kitchen and Lounge
address: Marriott Hotel Ikeja, 122 Joel Ogunnaike St, Ikeja GRA, Lagos 100271, Lagos
note: An Asian restaurant in Marriott Ikeja with a pretty interior, though food prep can be slow. Sunday open kitchen buffet for 49k includes two cocktails.
proTip: Their Sunday buffet has a nice variety. If you pick the 49k option, you get two cocktails.

name: Zanzan Suya at Lagos Polo Club
address: 1 Polo Rd, Ikoyi, Lagos 106104, Lagos
note: A suya spot within Lagos Polo Club, open to non-members as well. Caters to the ‘elite’ crowd, offering top-tier suya cuts.
proTip: Their gizzard and chicken suya are on another level.
